doc.after: Montreal has two international airports, one for passengers only, the other for cargo. MontrÃ©al-Pierre Elliott Trudeau International Airport (also known as Dorval Airport) in the City of Dorval serves all commercial passenger traffic and is the headquarters of Air Canada[186] and Air Transat.[187] To the north of the city is MontrÃ©al-Mirabel International Airport in Mirabel, which was envisioned as Montreal's primary airport but which now serves cargo flights along with MEDEVACs and general aviation and some passenger services.[188][189][190][191][192] In 2013, Montreal-Trudeau was the fourth busiest airport in Canada by passenger traffic and by aircraft movements, behind Toronto Pearson, Vancouver and Calgary, handling 14.09 million passengers in 2013,[193][194][195] and 207,882 aircraft movements in 2011.[196] With 60.8% of its passengers being on non-domestic flights it has the largest percentage of international flights of any Canadian airport.[197] Trudeau airport is served by 40 carriers to over 100 destinations worldwide.[198]
